curriculumTitle: Cultivating the Future: High School Agriculture & Horticulture STEM Pathway
overview: This comprehensive curriculum is designed for TRIO Upward Bound (UB) and Upward Bound Math-Science (UBMS) programs to guide high school students through the principles of modern agriculture and horticulture. It consists of 20 modular activities that integrate Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) with federal grant objectives. The curriculum covers soil science, hydroponic engineering, precision agriculture, genetics, coding, fluid dynamics, and career pathways, providing a holistic view of the 'Farm to Future' pipeline.
prerequisites: Basic Algebra I; 9th Grade Biology (recommended but not required); Signed Lab Safety Contract.
totalDurationEstimate: 20 sessions of 40 minutes (approx. 13-14 hours total contact time)

fieldTrips.name: Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Extension Center
fieldTrips.description: A tour of the Urban Agriculture and Forestry division, featuring controlled environment agriculture and turfgrass research.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Directly correlates to the hydroponics and precision agriculture modules, demonstrating university-level research applications.

fieldTrips.name: Botanical Research Institute of Texas (BRIT)
fieldTrips.description: Guided exploration of the herbarium and molecular genetics lab focused on plant conservation.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Connects to the 'Berry DNA Blueprint' and 'Mendel in the Garden' activities, showcasing professional botany careers.

fieldTrips.name: Harvest Project at The Dallas Arboretum
fieldTrips.description: The Rory Meyers Children's Adventure Garden focuses on life and earth science with a specific edible garden lab.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Reinforces soil science, photosynthesis, and plant physiology concepts covered in the first half of the curriculum.

fieldTrips.name: Cleburne State Park (Soil & Ecology Tour)
fieldTrips.description: Field study of soil erosion, limestone filtration, and native plant identification.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Provides real-world context for the 'Erosion Engineers' activity and environmental science standards.

activities.title: Soil Detectives: The Chemistry of Growth
activities.description: Students act as soil scientists to analyze soil samples for pH, Nitrogen, Phosphorus, and Potassium (N-P-K) levels. They will determine which crops are best suited for specific soil profiles and calculate necessary amendments.
learningObjectives: Analyze soil composition and chemical properties.
Understand the role of macronutrients in plant health.
Apply scientific methods to interpret data and make agricultural recommendations.
teks: 130.2(c)(10)(B) Identify the physical and chemical properties of soil.
112.35(c)(10)(A) Describe the unique role of carbon in biological systems (Chemistry).
130.25(c)(4)(A) Determine the chemical properties of soil.
texasStemStandards: Science Practices: Planning and carrying out investigations.
STEM Content: Environmental Science and Chemistry integration.

materialsList.item: Various Soil Samples (Sand, Clay, Potting Mix)

brief: Prepare soil samples A, B, C.
detailed: Prepare three distinct soil samples labeled A, B, and C prior to class.
Review the N-P-K cycle to ensure students understand what the tests represent.
Demonstrate proper handling of chemical reagents in the test kits.
Facilitate a discussion on how soil chemistry dictates regional agriculture.
Put on safety gear.
Take a small sample from your assigned soil bucket.
Follow the test kit instructions to mix soil with the reagent for pH, N, P, and K.
Compare color changes to the reference chart.
Record data and hypothesize which crop (e.g., corn, blueberries, tomatoes) would thrive in your sample.

trioCompliance.justification: This activity provides rigorous instruction in laboratory science (Chemistry/Environmental Science), a mandatory service for Upward Bound and UBMS per HEA.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b) - Support for rigorous secondary school program of study.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453 - Materials and supplies costs, including costs of computing devices.

stemConnections.science: Chemical reactions, soil ecology, and plant biology.
stemConnections.technology: Use of chemical indicators and colorimetric analysis.

activities.title: Hydro-Engineering: Designing Passive Systems
activities.description: Students explore sustainable horticulture by designing and building a small-scale Kratky (passive) hydroponic system. They will learn about water conservation and engineering design constraints.
learningObjectives: Compare and contrast traditional soil farming with hydroponics.
Construct a functional passive hydroponic system.
Understand root respiration and nutrient solution delivery.
teks: 112.34(c)(12)(B) Compare variations and adaptations of organisms in different ecosystems (Biology).
texasStemStandards: Engineering Design Process: Prototyping and testing.

materialsList.item: Wide-mouth Mason Jars or Recycled Plastic Containers

detailed: Pre-mix the nutrient solution to the correct dilution strength.
Explain the 'Kratky Method' theory: as water level drops, air space increases for oxygenation.
Discuss the benefits of hydroponics in urban food deserts (Equity/Society connection).
Guide students in assembling the jars without damaging plant roots.
Wash the clay pebbles to remove dust.
Place the seedling carefully into the net cup and support it with pebbles.
Fill your jar with nutrient solution until it just touches the bottom of the net cup.
Place the net cup into the jar opening.
Label your jar with your name and date.

allowableCosts: Educational Supplies (2 CFR 200.453) - Containers, media, plants.
trioCompliance.justification: Supports UBMS focus on engineering design and technology application in science. Covers UB core curriculum in lab science.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(a)(6) - Exposure to range of career options.

stemConnections.science: Plant physiology, root respiration, capillary action.
stemConnections.engineering: System design and structural integrity of the growing vessel.

activities.title: Precision Ag: Intro to GIS and Remote Sensing
activities.description: Students step into the role of an ag-tech specialist using simulated satellite imagery (printed heat maps) to identify crop stress. They will define zones for variable rate irrigation.
learningObjectives: Interpret Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) maps.
Understand how technology increases agricultural efficiency.
Analyze spatial data to make management decisions.
teks: 130.2(c)(5)(C) Discuss the impact of technology on agriculture.
111.43(c)(2)(A) Use mathematical models to solve problems (Math Models).
texasStemStandards: Technology Operations: Using systems to analyze data.

detailed: Introduce the concept of NDVI (healthy plants reflect near-infrared light).
Provide student groups with 'Field Maps' showing different colors (Green=Healthy, Red=Stressed).
Explain that 'Precision Agriculture' means treating different parts of a field differently.
Task students with calculating the percentage of the field that needs treatment.
Examine the field map provided.
Identify the 'Red Zones' where crops are failing.
Use the grid overlay to estimate the area (in acres) of the stressed zones.
Calculate how much fertilizer is saved if you only treat the stressed zones versus the whole field.
Draft a recommendation plan for the farmer.

allowableCosts: Software Licenses (if using paid GIS software)
trioCompliance.justification: Strongly aligns with UBMS mandate to provide instruction in mathematics and technology/computer science.

activities.title: The Business of Botany: Crop Yield Math
activities.description: A math-focused activity where students calculate potential yield and profit margins for different crops based on planting density, germination rates, and market prices.
learningObjectives: Apply algebraic formulas to real-world agricultural scenarios.
Calculate profit margins and break-even points.
Analyze risk factors in agricultural economics.
teks: 130.2(c)(9)(A) Explain the role of economics in agriculture.
111.43(c)(1)(B) Use probability and statistics to describe real-world situations (Math Models).

materialsList.item: Crop Data Sheets (Seeds per acre, Cost per seed, Market price)

detailed: Present the formula: Profit = (Yield Ã— Price) - (Input Costs).
Distribute crop profiles (e.g., Corn vs. Soybeans vs. Hemp).
Midway through the calculation, introduce a 'Scenario Card' (e.g., 'Unexpected freeze reduces yield by 20%') to force recalculation.
Discuss how farmers use math to hedge risks.
Select a crop profile.
Calculate the input cost for a 100-acre field based on seed price and density.
Calculate the Expected Yield based on standard germination rates.
Determine total revenue.
Draw a 'Risk Card' and adjust your final profit calculation.
Determine if your farm stayed profitable.

trioCompliance.justification: Directly satisfies the 'Instruction in Mathematics' component required by UB/UBMS, while also touching on financial literacy.

activities.title: Ag-Careers: Beyond the Tractor
activities.description: Students research and simulate interviews for high-tech careers in agriculture (e.g., Drone Pilot, Food Scientist, Ag Engineer, Hydrologist) to broaden their understanding of the field.
learningObjectives: Identify STEM careers within the agriculture sector.
Research educational requirements for specific careers.
Practice professional communication and interview skills.
texasStemStandards: Career Readiness: Understanding labor market trends.

detailed: Debunk the myth that agriculture is only about 'farming and manual labor'.
Assign each student a specific high-tech role to research.
Set up a 'Speed Networking' arrangement where students explain their job to a peer in 2 minutes.
Wrap up with a discussion on college majors that lead to these careers.
Use the tablet to research your assigned career (Salary, Degree Required, Daily Tasks).
Fill out the Career Profile Template.
Prepare a 60-second 'elevator pitch' about why your job is crucial to feeding the world.
Participate in the speed networking round.

allowableServices: Academic Advice and Assistance in Course Selection
allowableCosts: Speaker Fees (if bringing in a professional)
Field Trip Costs (if visiting a university ag dept)
trioCompliance.justification: Fulfills the mandatory service of providing information on career options and exposure to academic programs.
heaRequirements: Sec. 402C(b) - Guidance on secondary school reentry/entry to postsecondary.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.421 - Advertising and public relations (outreach materials).

activities.title: Mendel in the Garden: Probability and Genetics
activities.description: Students explore classical genetics by predicting phenotype ratios using Punnett squares and observing 'Fast Plant' variations. They will understand the probability of inherited traits in crops.
learningObjectives: Predict offspring genotypes and phenotypes using Punnett squares.
Understand dominant and recessive traits in agriculture.
Calculate probability percentages for desired crop traits.
teks: 112.34(c)(6)(F) Predict possible outcomes of various genetic combinations.
130.25(c)(7)(A) Explain the benefits of plant breeding.
texasStemStandards: Science Practices: Using models to represent systems.
Math in Science: Probability and statistics.

detailed: Review Gregor Mendel's laws of inheritance.
Explain how farmers use these principles to breed larger or sweeter crops.
Have students plant the Fast Seeds (which grow in weeks) to eventually verify predictions.
Determine the genotype of the parent plants provided.
Fill out the Punnett square to predict the ratio of purple vs. green stems.
Calculate the percentage chance of a recessive trait appearing.
Plant the seeds to test your prediction.

trioCompliance.justification: Biology (Genetics) is a core high school science component supported by UB/UBMS instruction.

collegePathways: BS in Plant Breeding and Genetics

activities.title: Coding the Harvest: Micro-Controllers in Ag
activities.description: Introduction to agricultural automation. Students code a microcontroller (e.g., Micro:bit or Arduino) to read a soil moisture sensor and display a visual alert when water is needed.
learningObjectives: Write basic code loops and conditional statements (If/Then).
Interface hardware sensors with digital code.
Understand the concept of Internet of Things (IoT) in farming.
teks: 130.2(c)(5)(C) Discuss impact of technology in agriculture.

detailed: Demonstrate the block-based coding interface (MakeCode or Scratch).
Explain how a sensor sends an analog signal that the computer reads as a number.
Discuss how this technology saves water on massive industrial farms.
Connect the moisture sensor to the microcontroller using alligator clips.
Write a code block: 'If reading < 500, show Sad Face'.
Write a code block: 'If reading > 500, show Happy Face'.
Test the sensor in dry soil versus wet soil.

trioCompliance.justification: Core computer science and engineering instruction, specifically targeted at UBMS participants.

activities.title: Solar Scouting: Agrivoltaics Physics
activities.description: Students investigate 'Agrivoltaics' (mixing solar panels with farming). They simulate shade patterns to determine which crops can grow under solar panels, exploring light angles and energy efficiency.
learningObjectives: Understand the relationship between solar angle and shadow length.
Analyze the benefits of dual-use land (Energy + Food).
Measure light intensity (lumens).
teks: 112.39(c)(6)(D) Investigate the characteristics of waves (Light) - Physics.

detailed: Introduce Agrivoltaics: Plants cool the panels, panels shade the plants.
Have students angle flashlights to simulate morning, noon, and evening sun.
Discuss crops that prefer partial shade (lettuce, spinach).
Set up your model solar farm using cardboard.
Move the flashlight in an arc to simulate the sun's path.
Measure light intensity under the panels using the Lux meter.
Map out the 'planting zones' that receive enough light for photosynthesis.

trioCompliance.justification: Physics instruction regarding light and energy, aligned with environmental sustainability.

activities.title: The pH of Preservation: Food Science
activities.description: Students learn the chemistry of food preservation by testing acidity levels. They simulate the canning process to understand how pH prevents botulism and microbial growth.
learningObjectives: Define pH and its importance in food safety.
Identify the threshold pH (4.6) for safe water-bath canning.
Understand microbial growth inhibition.

detailed: Explain that low acid foods (pH > 4.6) require pressure canning to kill bacteria.
Discuss Botulism as a biological hazard.
Demonstrate how adding vinegar (acid) changes the safety profile of a food.
Mash small samples of different foods.
Test the pH of each sample.
Sort foods into 'Safe for Water Bath' (High Acid) and 'Needs Pressure' (Low Acid).
Add vinegar to a Low Acid food and test if it shifts to the Safe zone.

trioCompliance.justification: Chemistry application in a real-world context (Food Science), fitting the science instruction component.

activities.title: Berry DNA Blueprint: Biotech Basics
activities.description: A hands-on biotechnology lab where students extract DNA from strawberries using household materials. They will visualize the genetic material that ag-scientists modify.
learningObjectives: Perform a DNA extraction protocol.
Understand the structure and function of DNA in plants.
Discuss the concept of GMOs (Genetically Modified Organisms).
teks: 130.25(c)(8)(A) Explain the use of biotechnology in agriculture.

detailed: Explain that soap breaks the cell membrane and salt helps DNA clump.
Discuss that strawberries are octoploid (8 copies of chromosomes), yielding a lot of DNA.
Facilitate a neutral discussion on the ethics/science of GMOs.
Smash a strawberry in a bag with the extraction liquid (soap/salt/water).
Filter the liquid into a cup.
Slowly pour cold alcohol on top.
Watch the white strands (DNA) precipitate out of the solution.
Spool the DNA on a stick.

trioCompliance.justification: Classic biology lab activity fulfilling the laboratory science requirement for UB/UBMS.

activities.title: Vertical Farm Architects: Structural Engineering
activities.description: Students work in teams to design and build a model of a vertical farm tower that must support a specific weight (water/plants) while minimizing footprint, utilizing structural engineering principles.
learningObjectives: Apply structural engineering concepts (load distribution, triangles).
Design for space efficiency.
Test and iterate on a physical prototype.
teks: 130.362(c)(5)(A) Describe the inputs and outputs of an engineering system.

detailed: Introduce Vertical Farming as a solution to urban population density.
Explain that water is heavy (8 lbs/gallon), so structures must be strong.
Challenge: Build the tallest tower that can hold a 1lb weight using limited materials.
Sketch a design for your tower.
Construct the tower using the provided materials.
Test the tower by adding weights incrementally.
Identify failure points and reinforce them.

trioCompliance.justification: Engineering design challenge focused on physics and structural integrity, ideal for UBMS.

activities.title: Erosion Engineers: Soil Conservation
activities.description: Students simulate rainfall on different land slopes to observe soil erosion. They must engineer a mitigation strategy (terracing, cover crops) to reduce soil loss.
learningObjectives: Understand the mechanics of soil erosion.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different conservation methods.
Relate soil health to water quality.
teks: 112.37(c)(7)(B) Analyze the impact of human activity on land.

detailed: Discuss the 'Dust Bowl' as a historical example of failed soil management.
Explain how run-off carries pollutants into waterways.
Challenge students to keep the water running off their 'land' as clear as possible.
Set up a slope using the pan and soil.
Pour water and measure the amount of soil that washes away (Control).
Rebuild the slope and install a defense (terraces, dams, or plant cover).
Pour water again and compare the sediment loss.

trioCompliance.justification: Environmental science activity addressing ecology and measurement.

activities.title: Aquaponic Synergy: The Nitrogen Cycle
activities.description: Students investigate the symbiotic relationship between fish and plants. They test water samples from an aquaponic setup for Ammonia, Nitrite, and Nitrate to understand the bacterial conversion cycle.
learningObjectives: Diagram the Nitrogen Cycle.
Explain the role of Nitrosomonas and Nitrobacter bacteria.
Analyze water chemistry data to ensure fish and plant safety.
teks: 112.37(c)(6)(D) Relate the flow of matter (Carbon/Nitrogen cycles) to energy flow.

materialsList.item: Aquarium Water Samples (Spiked with Ammonia for testing)

detailed: Draw the cycle: Fish Waste (Ammonia) -> Bacteria 1 (Nitrite) -> Bacteria 2 (Nitrate) -> Plants (Food).
Explain that Ammonia and Nitrite are toxic to fish, but Nitrate is plant food.
Have students test samples representing different stages of a new tank setup.
Test Sample A, B, and C.
Record the PPM (parts per million) of Ammonia, Nitrite, and Nitrate.
Determine which sample comes from a 'cycled' (healthy) system and which is toxic.
Explain why plants are the 'filter' in this system.

trioCompliance.justification: High-level biology/chemistry application involving the nitrogen cycle, essential for HS science curriculum.

activities.title: Logistics of Lunch: Supply Chain Math
activities.description: A math and logic activity where students map the journey of a strawberry from farm to table. They use graph theory (nodes and edges) to optimize transport routes and minimize carbon footprint.
learningObjectives: Apply graph theory/network math to real-world problems.
Calculate fuel costs and carbon emissions.
Optimize logistical routes.
teks: 111.45(c)(3)(A) Use graph theory to model situations (Discrete Math).
texasStemStandards: Math in Context: Logistics and optimization.

detailed: Introduce the 'Traveling Salesman Problem' concept.
Provide a map with distribution centers, farms, and grocery stores.
Assign a cost per mile and a carbon cost per mile.
Draw a network graph connecting the farm to the customer via processing plants.
Calculate the total distance for three different routes.
Determine the most cost-effective route.
Determine the most eco-friendly route (they might differ!).

trioCompliance.justification: Advanced mathematics (Discrete Math/Graph Theory) applied to industry, fitting the UBMS rigor.

activities.title: Integrated Pest Detective: Entomology Lab
activities.description: Students use microscopes to identify common agricultural pests (aphids, mites) versus beneficial insects (ladybugs). They design an Integrated Pest Management (IPM) plan.
learningObjectives: Identify insects using dichotomous keys.
Differentiate between pests and beneficials.
Design an IPM strategy that minimizes chemical use.

detailed: Explain IPM: Biological control (bugs eating bugs) vs. Chemical control.
Show students how to adjust the microscope focus.
Discuss the economic threshold: When does the cost of bugs exceed the cost of treatment?
Observe the specimen under the lens.
Use the dichotomous key (Does it have wings? How many legs?) to identify it.
Classify it as 'Friend' or 'Foe'.
Propose a way to control the 'Foe' without hurting the 'Friend'.

trioCompliance.justification: Biology lab instruction focusing on taxonomy and ecology.

activities.title: Fluid Dynamics in Irrigation: Physics of Flow
activities.description: Students explore Bernoulli's principle and pressure by designing a gravity-fed drip irrigation system. They calculate flow rates and ensure equal water distribution.
learningObjectives: Understand the relationship between height (head), pressure, and flow rate.
Calculate water usage over time.
Design a system with uniform distribution.

detailed: Explain that raising the water source increases pressure (Potential Energy).
Challenge students: Can you make the last hole in the tube drip as fast as the first?
Discuss friction loss in pipes.
Assemble a tubing line with holes every 6 inches.
Elevate the water bucket to 1 foot and measure flow rate at the first and last hole.
Elevate to 3 feet and measure again.
Graph the relationship between height and flow rate.

trioCompliance.justification: Physics and engineering focus, analyzing fluid dynamics and calculation.

stemConnections.math: Calculus concepts (rates of change) simplified to algebra.

activities.title: Drone Flight Pathing: Geometry in the Sky
activities.description: Students plan a flight path for an agricultural drone to scan a field efficiently. They use geometry to ensure 100% coverage with minimal battery usage.
learningObjectives: Apply geometric concepts (Area, Perimeter, Parallel lines).
Optimize a path algorithm.
Understand field-of-view (FOV) calculations.
teks: 130.2(c)(5)(B) Demonstrate use of global positioning systems.

detailed: Introduce the concept of 'swath width' (how wide the camera sees).
Show examples of 'snake' patterns vs. 'spiral' patterns.
Give students an oddly shaped field map to complicate the path.
Calculate the area of the field.
Given a camera swath of 20ft, draw a flight path that covers the whole field.
Calculate the total distance flown.
Adjust the path to minimize turns (which waste battery).

trioCompliance.justification: Applied geometry and technology exposure (UAVs).

activities.title: Compost Thermodynamics: The Heat is On
activities.description: Students explore exothermic chemical reactions by building mini-compost piles. They measure temperature changes over time to understand microbial respiration.
learningObjectives: Define exothermic reactions.
Understand the Carbon:Nitrogen ratio (Browns vs Greens).
Graph temperature data over time.

detailed: Explain that bacteria release heat as they break down food (just like humans).
Discuss the Ideal C:N ratio (30:1).
Have students mix different ratios to see which gets hottest.
Layer 'Greens' (Nitrogen) and 'Browns' (Carbon) in the bottle.
Add water to dampen.
Insert the thermometer.
Record the temperature.
Predict how hot it will get by the next session.

trioCompliance.justification: Chemistry and Environmental Science instruction focusing on energy and reactions.

activities.title: Fungal Frontiers: Mycology Lab
activities.description: Students learn about the kingdom Fungi by inoculating substrate with mushroom spores. They explore the role of mycelium in soil networks and decomposition.
learningObjectives: Differentiate Fungi from Plants.
Understand the role of decomposers in the ecosystem.
Practice sterile laboratory technique.

detailed: Explain that mushrooms are more closely related to animals than plants.
Discuss the 'Wood Wide Web' (mycelial networks).
Emphasize sterility: mold competes with mushrooms.
Sterilize your workspace and hands.
Pasteurize the substrate (teacher does this beforehand or demonstrates).
Mix the mushroom spawn into the substrate.
Seal the bag and punch air holes.
Observe mycelial run (white web) over the coming weeks.

trioCompliance.justification: Biology lab instruction focusing on microbiology and sterile technique.

activities.title: Capstone: The Martian Greenhouse
activities.description: The final challenge. Students synthesize all previous knowledge (soil, hydro, light, genetics) to design a food production system for a Mars colony, accounting for extreme constraints.
learningObjectives: Synthesize multi-disciplinary STEM knowledge.
Solve problems under extreme constraints (Low light, no soil, high radiation).
Present a cohesive technical proposal.
teks: 112.33(c)(4)(A) Evaluate the impact of space research.

detailed: Set the scene: Mars has 40% less sunlight, toxic soil, and limited water.
Divide students into specialist teams (Engineers, Biologists, Chemists).
Facilitate the design process.
Collaborate to design a greenhouse module.
Select the crop (Fast plants? High calorie?).
Select the method (Hydroponics? Treated regolith?).
Select the energy source.
Draw the schematic and justify your choices based on data from previous weeks.

trioCompliance.justification: Comprehensive STEM synthesis activity measuring student mastery of the curriculum.
